item.title: Juliet add a quote by C.D. Wright
item.description: "I am suggesting that the radical of poetry lies not in the resolution of doubts but in their proliferation" -- C.D. Wright

item.title: Juliet add a quote by C.D. Wright
item.description: "Almost none of the poetries I admire stick to their labels, native or adopted ones. Rather, they are vagrant in their identifications. Tramp poets, there you go, a new label for those with unstable allegiances." -- C.D. Wright

item.title: Juliet add a quote by C.D. Wright
item.description:
"Nobody reads poetry, we are told at every inopportune moment. I read poetry. I am somebody. I am the people, too. It can be allowed that an industrious quantity of contemporary American poetry is consciously written for a hermetic constituency; the bulk is written for the bourgeoisie, leaving a lean cut for labor. Only the hermetically aimed has a snowball's chance in hell of reaching its intended ears. One proceeds from this realization. A staggering figure of vibrant, intelligent people can and do live without poetry, especially without the poetry of their time. This figure includes the unemployed, the rank and file, the union brass, banker, scientist, lawyer, doctor, architect, pilot, and priest. It also includes most academics, most of the faculty of the humanities, most allegedly literary editors and most allegedly literary critics. They do so--go forward in their lives, toward their great reward, in an engulfing absence of poetry--without being perceived or perceiving themselves as hobbled or deficient in any significant way. It is nearly true, though I am often reminded of a Transtromer broadside I saw in a crummy office building in San Francisco:
We got dressed and showed the house
You live well the visitor said
The slum must be inside you.
If I wanted to understand a culture, my own for instance, and if I thought such an understanding were the basis for a lifelong inquiry, I would turn to poetry first. For it is my confirmed bias that the poets remain the most 'stunned by existence,' the most determined to redeem the world in words.." -- C.D. Wright

item.title: Juliet add a quote by C.D. Wright
item.description: "Poetry seems especially like nothing else so much as itself. Poetry is not like, it is the very lining of the inner life." -- C.D. Wright

item.title: Juliet add a quote by C.D. Wright
item.description: "Poetry is the language of intensity. Because we are going to die, an expression of intensity is justified." -- C.D. Wright

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Laura Moriarty
item.description: "One way to remain unfinished is to stop. the other is to go on." -- Laura Moriarty

item.title: Juliet add a quote by C.D. Wright
item.description: "If the incision of our words amounts to nothing but a feeling, a slow motion, it will still cut a better swath than the factory model, the corporate model, the penitentiary model, which by my lights are one and the same." -- C.D. Wright

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Ed Wood
item.description: "You're the ruler of the universe. Try to show a little taste!" -- Ed Wood

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Mary Ruefle
item.description: "Something unpronounceable followed by a long silence points out my life is becoming a landscape." -- Mary Ruefle

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Sylvia Plath
item.description: "Mother of otherness, Eat me." -- Sylvia Plath

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Sylvia Plath
item.description: "A black-sharded lady keeps me in a parrot cage." -- Sylvia Plath

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Lara Glenum
item.description: "On detonation, red sugar spilled out of the corner of my mouth." -- Lara Glenum

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Lara Glenum
item.description: "Each note is inscribed on a sugar cube lodged in the hoof of a rabid pig." -- Lara Glenum

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Jasper Fforde
item.description: "Whereas story is processed in the mind in a straightforward manner, poetry bypasses rational thought and goes straight to the limbic system and lights it up like a brushfire. It's the crack cocaine of the literary world." -- Jasper Fforde

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Robert Frost
item.description: "A poem begins as a lump in the throat, a sense of wrong, a homesickness, a lovesickness." -- Robert Frost

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Chelsey Minnis
item.description:
"I will tell you what is poetry...
It is a remote electronic claw picking up a stuffed bunny rabbit..." -- Chelsey Minnis

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Dean Young
item.description: "A poem should be odd as a small cast-iron platypus." -- Dean Young

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Cate Marvin
item.description: "I think with my blood." -- Cate Marvin

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Jean-Paul Sartre
item.description: "If you're lonely when you're alone, you're in bad company." -- Jean-Paul Sartre

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Bernard M. Baruch
item.description: "Be who you are and say what you feel, because those who mind don't matter, and those who matter don't mind." -- Bernard M. Baruch

item.title: Juliet add a quote by John Waters
item.description: "If you go home with somebody, and they don't have books, don't fuck 'em!" -- John Waters

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Friedrich Nietzsche
item.description: "Is life not a thousand times too short for us to bore ourselves?" -- Friedrich Nietzsche

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Edgar Allan Poe
item.description: "Those who dream by day are cognizant of many things which escape those who dream only by night." -- Edgar Allan Poe

item.title: Juliet add a quote by Juliet Cook
item.description: "I once typed 'vagina dentata' into dictionary.com and it asked me, 'Did you mean giant anteater?" -- Juliet Cook
